Award.AwardTitle: Environmental Scholars: An Interdisciplinary Scholarship Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The Environmental Scholars Program is supporting three cohorts of academically talented students with demonstrated financial need in attaining baccalaureate degrees in chemistry, environmental forest biology, environmental resources engineering and environmental science at the SUNY College of Environmental Science and Forestry. In addition to scholarship aid, the project is engaging scholars through a series of activities with a unifying theme of global environmental change, including cross-disciplinary and career-preparation seminars, service-learning projects which emphasize science communication, and capstone research experiences. The intellectual merit of the project lies in its comprehensive plan to support scholars through a rigorous cross-disciplinary academic program in an area of national need. Broader impacts include leveraging partnerships to support energetic recruiting for a diverse talent pool and to provide internship and career-advancement opportunities to connect graduates with the STEM workforce and graduate programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

In the fall of 2014, the SUNY College of Environmental Science and Forestry (ESF), in partnership with the National Science Foundation, launched the NSF SSTEM Environmental Scholars program. The Environmental Scholars program focused on three main goals: 1) creating and fostering a diverse cohort of students with significant financial need and strong scientific talent, 2) creating an environment for interdisciplinary discourse by using global climate change as a primary focus, and 3) graduating students with the skills and education necessary to join the STEM workforce and/or pursue post-baccalaureate degrees in STEM disciplines.

The Environmental Scholars program ran from the fall of 2014 through the fall of 2020 and included 36 students in four cohorts. A majority of program participants, 58%, came to ESF from states outside of New York. Fifty-eight percent of Environmental Scholars were from populations underrepresented in STEM fields, and 52.7% of Scholars were female. The Environmental Scholars represented five unique majors of study:

1)    Biology ? 41.6%

2)    Environmental Science -  22.2%

3)    Environmental Resources Engineering - 16.8%

4)    Bio Process Engineering - 11.1%

5)    Chemistry ? 8.3%

At the programs conclusion, 72.2% of Environmental Scholars had graduated or were still enrolled and progressing toward degree completion. One hundred percent of Environmental Scholar graduates entered into STEM fields or into STEM graduate programs.  

Intellectual Merit:

The Environmental Scholars program established a diverse cohort of students with a variety of perspectives from both lived experience and academic preparation. Scholars began their tenure at ESF with a trip to the Adirondack Mountains and a dinner networking event with faculty and the College President, held at the President?s residence. With an established network for success and an enhanced sense of belonging and integration into the ESF campus community, Scholars built confidence and motivation for their academic journey. The program honored Scholars? varied interests in STEM fields and engaged them in interdisciplinary discourse and intellectual sharing. With global climate change as a primary focus, students were empowered to explore concepts, learn from their peers, and critically analyze and communicate understanding with faculty mentors and collaborative faculty and professional panels. 

Broader Impacts:

The primary impacts of the Environmental Scholars program were enhancing access for low-income students, building confidence, and supporting career preparation and pathways to STEM employment and graduate programs. The Environmental Scholars were recognized on campus for their exceptional academic achievement and carried this sense of pride through their time at ESF and into their careers. Cultivating their interest in STEM with individualized support and group engagement opportunities, the Environmental Scholars have said it best as they shared these reflections on the impacts the program had on them:

-       This program motivated me to participate in events and now I am more prepared and without doubt in myself.

-       The opportunity this program provided me with a scholarship meant I had a chance at a professional career in STEM and I did it!

-       I am confident and ready for my career because of this program and already have a job in the field I love before graduation.

-       The Scholars program helped me learn to see environmental problems from many perspectives, knowing there are multiple valid ways people see a single issue has helped me in my personal life too.

-       This program helped me see the future and gave me a push to succeed. I made the Dean?s list every semester because of the program.

-       This program made me feel special just by being accepted. I felt like someone believed in me and thought I had potential and I genuinely believe this program is the reason I am here and have such a high GPA.

-       At the end, the focus on career readiness, using our strengths, and developing (designing) a path forward was beneficial to my decision of what career suited me best.
